attributes.title: Testing a simulation based account for the other production effect

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Simulation and other-production. We are investigating a simulation-based account for the other-production effect – that is, that words read aloud by somebody else are better remembered than words read silently because we simulate the other’s act of production using some of the same mechanisms that are used when we read the word aloud ourselves. This project is run by Samuel Beech as part of his final year dissertation at Cardiff University.

other.value: We will be recording the vocalisations of participants. This allows us to check for any errors such as not reading the words in time, mispronouncing words or the incorrect participant producing the word.

sample.value: 24 pairs of participants, 48 participants overall. Each participant will provide 120 data points, or 20 in each of 6 conditions.

analyses.value: 2-way ANOVAs on arcsin-transformed % of correct “sure-old” judgments, with participants as the source of variability. Follow-up analyses will use logistic linear-mixed effect models to model the probability of a word being correctly recognised, with both participants and words as crossed random effects. We will also (1) ordinal regression analyses of the 4-point ratings using cumulative link mixed models and (2) ANOVAs of the discriminability index (da), computed from ROC curves (for details of the latter two methods, see Rommers et al., 2020).

outliers.value: We will follow the same procedures as in Rommers et al. (2020). Thus, we will exclude words for which the participants did not follow instructions correctly in the word reading task (read words aloud that they were meant to, without disfluencies or produced no sound when asked to remain silent).

dependent.value: The dependant variable is memory recognition of the target words presented following the sentence. This will be measured in a separate word recognition task performed shortly after the word reading task (with a math task in the middle; see Rommers et al., 2020). Participants will be presented will all target words and an equal number of novel words and asked to identify either: -Sure the word is new -It might be new -It might be old -Sure it was old. The percentage of old target words correctly recognised (i.e., judged sure old) will be used as the dependent variable. Previous research (Rommers et al., 2020) shows that “maybe old” judgements were not affected by condition (self vs. silent), whereas “sure-old” judgements were.

conditions.value: Using a within-subjects design participants will provide data in all conditions. We are using a 3x2 design. The first independent variable is how the sentence prior to the target word is read. Either both participants read it silently or participants vocalise each word of the sentence in an alternating fashion. The second variable is if and how the target word is produced, either both participant A and B read it silently, A reads it while B is silent, or B reads it while A is silent.

hypothesis.value:
The production effect is a robust finding showing that we have better memory for words when we read them aloud compared to when reading them silently. The other-production effect is the finding that words heard when produced by someone else are remembered better than words read silently (MacLeod, 2011). In previous studies the magnitude of the other-production effect was smaller than that of the self-production effect. We are investigating a simulation-based account for the other-production effect – that is, that words read aloud by somebody else are better remembered than words read silently because we simulate the other’s act of production using some of the same mechanisms that are used when we read the word aloud ourselves (Gambi & Pickering, 2011). 
To test whether we replicate previous findings (i.e., the production effect and the other-production effect), we will ask pairs of participants to take turns reading words out loud or reading them silently. Further, in order to try and manipulate the extent to which participants engage in simulation of their partner’s acts of production, we will ask them to either take turns reading sentence contexts aloud (one word each at a time; which we expect to encourage simulation) or to read them silently. On each trial, participants will be shown a sentence context, presented one word at a time in RSVP, which each word coloured in green, orange or violet, followed by the target word in white. The colour of the sentence context specifies who should read the final target word (i.e., condition): either participant A reads it aloud, participant B reads it aloud, or both participants read it silently. The sentence contexts were taken from Rommers, Dell, & Benjamin (2020) and were all unpredictable (i.e., low Cloze probability).
The second manipulation (high or low simulation) is blocked (order counterbalanced across participants). In the high simulation condition, participants alternate reading words from the context out loud (one each), and the position of the fixation cross on the screen before the sentence context (right or left) indicates which participant begins on each trial, by reading the first word of the sentence. The low simulation condition involves reading the whole sentence silently. 
There are three hypotheses for the interaction between condition and simulation (both manipulated within participants). As specified below (see point 5), we will conduct an omnibus analysis first, with condition as a three-level factor (self, other, silent). This will be followed-up with analyses comparing self to silent (i.e., the self-production effect), other to silent (i.e., the other-production effect) and self to other (i.e., to assess to what degree reading a word out loud is comparable to hearing a word read aloud by one’s partner). We do not expect the magnitude of the self-production effect to differ across high and low simulation blocks. Instead, we expect the magnitude of the other-production effect to be affected by simulation. If our hypotheses are correct, changes in the magnitude of the other-production effect will thus also lead to changes in the magnitude of the difference between self and other. Below, we describe our hypotheses with reference to the magnitude of the other-production effect (Other vs. Silent X High vs. Low Simulation).
1.	If there is no interaction between condition (other vs. silent) and simulation, this would suggest simulation has no effect on the magnitude of other-production effect, and so simulation is unlikely to be contributing to enhanced memory for words read aloud by a partner. 
2.	If there is significant interaction between condition (other vs. silent) and simulation, then post-hoc analyses will be used to determine whether the size of the other-production effect is larger in low or in high simulation.
a.	One possibility is that the memory benefit associated with other-production will increase in high simulation compared to low simulation, because engaging in simulation of one’s partner’s acts of production more will make the other condition more akin to the self condition. 
b.	However, it is also possible that simulation is already maximally engaged when hearing one’s partner’s speaking (i.e., even in low simulation blocks) as it is the default process when engaging in a joint task. If so, our manipulation should not affect memory performance in the other condition much, but it may instead affect how likely participants are to simulate their partner’s even when they are not speaking (i.e., in the silent condition); if so, we would expect the magnitude of the other-production effect to be smaller in high than low simulation blocks, because high simulation blocks should boost memory performance even in the silent condition (see Rommers, et al., 2020 for a related argument about effects of sentence predictability on simulation). (Note. If this latter hypothesis is correct, the size of the self-production effect should also be reduced in high compared to low simulation).

attributes.title: Dynamic Development of Intuition and Explicit Knowledge During Implicit Learning Paradigm

q1.value: Dynamic Development of Intuitions and Explicit Knowledge During Implicit Learning Paradigm

q3.value: Intuitions have been theorized to precede explicit awareness of information that is – at least initially – acquired implicitly (Epstein, 2010; Hodgkinson et al., 2008; Lieberman, 2000; Reber, 1989). In other words, intuitions develop based on incomplete implicit perceptions of regularity and coherence, and, in turn, influence subsequent beliefs, knowledge, and behavior (Bechara & Damasio, 2005; Epstein, 2010; Hodgkinson et al., 2008; Pacini & Epstein, 1999). However, there is surprisingly little empirical work to support intuitions based on implicit learning. The role of intuition on the development of more explicit knowledge and beliefs is also largely unknown. The present study will investigate the emergence of intuitions during an implicit learning paradigm, and examine how the accuracy of such intuitions influence later explicit knowledge.

q4.value:
1. Accurate intuitions will emerge prior to explicit knowledge… If intuitions develop from implicitly learned information, and serve as a bridge between nonconscious and more explicit representations, then individuals should report accurate intuitions of implicitly learned material prior to gaining explicit knowledge of the information. 

2. Individual differences in implicit learning will predict development of intuitions… Intuitions are said to develop based on incomplete perceptions of regularity or coherence. Therefore, stronger implicit learners should provide more accurate intuitions. We further hypothesize that they may develop intuitions more quickly.  

3. Explicit knowledge will be related to the quality of intuitions… We expect to observe a significant, positive association between accuracy of intuitions and explicit knowledge. 

4. Intuitions will influence the relationship between implicit learning and explicit knowledge… If intuitions serve as a bridge between implicit and explicit knowledge, the accuracy of one’s intuitions may mediate the effect of implicit learning on later explicit knowledge.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Participants will complete a modified version of the Serial Reaction Time Task (SRTT), a widely-used measure of implicit learning in which subjects must respond to dots that rapidly appear/disappear at different locations onscreen (some “blocks” are patterned; others are random; Nissen & Bullemer, 1987). Implicit learning is operationalized as the difference between random vs. patterned blocks to distinguish implicit learning from mere familiarity (Robertson, 2007).

After performing a number of SRTT blocks, participants will be informed that, at various points during the task, the dots will appear in a reoccurring pattern. They will then be instructed to indicate (1) when they have an intuition about whether the block is random or patterned and (2) when they are explicitly aware of whether or not there is a pattern. Participants will signal such knowledge be pressing a specific key on the keyboard, at which point they will be direct to a new screen and asked to indicate their level of knowledge. Participants who report explicit knowledge of a pattern will be asked to reproduce it. 

Notably, the experimental design allows for the possibility that participants may report explicit knowledge prior to reporting an intuition. We have intentionally allowed for this possibility in order to gain empirical support for our first hypothesis – and frequently-cited line of thinking – that intuitions emerge before explicit knowledge. However, in instances when a participant reports explicit knowledge before/without giving an intuition, we will take some steps to assess whether the knowledge is actually explicit. Because participants must reproduce the pattern if they report explicit knowledge, we will be able to ascertain whether or not their knowledge is likely to be explicit. For example, if a participant indicates explicit knowledge but cannot accurately indicate most of the repeating pattern, we may reclassify this report as an intuition. 

All participants will complete the same blocks, but order will be counterbalanced randomly. 

IV 1: Implicit learning: Operationalized as difference in responding during patterned vs. random blocks

DV 1: Intuitions: Operationalized both in terms of accuracy (e.g., does participant have an intuition of a pattern during a pattern block?) and speed (how long into the block before the participant reports an intuition). See above for alternative ways we may score intuition. 

DV 2: Explicit Knowledge: Operationalized both in terms of accuracy (e.g., does participant have explicit knowledge of a pattern during a pattern block? How many sequence elements can the participant reproduce?) and speed (how long into the block before the participant reports explicit knowledge).

MV 1: Intuitions -> does accuracy/speed of intuitions mediate relationship between implicit learning and explicit knowledge?

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: Additional data collection prior to this registration was used for task development. No previously collected data will be used in the experiment/analyses described in this registration.

question.value:
Data will be collected online through Prolific (https://www.prolific.co/). Participants will be paid approximately $9.00/hr. All participants who did not participate in previous version of this study (i.e., piloting) will be able to view the study. Participants will be eligible if they meet the following requirements: normal intellectual function, no significant medical disorder, age 18-55, not financially attached to Georgetown University, & fluent in English. 

Over the course of completing the study, participants will encounter a number of “attention checks”. Failure to respond appropriately to these questions will indicate inappropriate attention; participants who fail these questions will be excluded from analysis. Finally, the duration of each participants’ time to complete the study will be obtained; irregular completion times may also serve as grounds for exclusion.

q13.value: Target sample size for this study is 100-125 participants, which will give us 80% power to detect a small-to-medium effect size for a linear regression model with up to 5 predictors at an alpha probability of .05. We will attempt to recruit 125-150 participants to account for any exclusions based on participant attention.

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power to perform a power analysis for a linear regression model with up to 5 predictors. Our goal was to obtain 80% power to detect a small to medium effect size (.1 - .15) at alpha error probability of .05.

question.value:
Primary, hypothesis-driven variables: 

IV 1: Implicit Learning… Implicit learning will be operationalized as the difference in responding on patterned vs random blocks. This will be measured using mixed effects models, with target information (i.e., target number in the sequence, block type: pattern or random, button combination, target number x block type interaction) as Level 1 variables and Participant as the Level 2 variable. RT will be used as the DV. The first 10 targets of each block will be excluded to allow for a brief familiarization. We will also exclude all targets with an RT > 1000ms. Block condition will be treated as a random slope. All other level 1 variables will set to random if doing so improves model fit. In order to obtain a measure of implicit learning for each participant, we will estimate each participant’s variance from the average slope of block condition (using the most parsimonious model). 

DV 1: Intuitions… Participants will indicate the precise moment at which they develop intuitions. When they do this, participants will be directed to a separate screen to report whether they have an intuition that the targets are appearing as a pattern or an intuition that they are appearing randomly. We will record whether their intuitions are accurate as well as how many targets passed before they stopped the sequence to indicate the intuition. Both of these metrics (accuracy vs timing) may prove useful. If we observe a negative correlation between timing and accuracy (i.e., faster participants are more accurate), we may create a composite measure that incorporates both accuracy and timing. This measurement of intuition will serve as both a DV (as it relates to implicit learning) and as a MV (implicit learning  intuitions  explicit knowledge). Further, because participants are permitted to report explicit knowledge prior to intuitions, it will be important to determine whether explicit knowledge reported prior to an intuition is, in fact, explicit. Participants will be required to reproduce the pattern if they report explicit knowledge of a pattern. If participants who report explicit knowledge before an intuition are unable to demonstrate explicit knowledge (because they cannot produce the pattern), we may reclassify this judgement as an intuition. 

DV 2: Explicit Knowledge… Participants will also indicate when they have explicit knowledge of the pattern (again, by stopping the sequence). We will measure explicit knowledge by considering both accuracy and speed. Additionally, because participants will be asked to reproduce the pattern if they report explicit knowledge, we will also record the number of correct sequence elements that each participant can recall. We will examine how all 3 estimates of explicit knowledge relate to each other.

Secondary, exploratory variables:

We will collect additional information on each participant. The below variables may be used in additional exploratory regression based models to examine how the emergence of intuitions relates to other cognitive abilities and personality traits. If we find that these variables are meaningfully related to implicit learning and the emergence of intuitions/explicit knowledge, they may be used as covariate regressors in the primary analyses to obtain a more precise estimate of the effect of implicit learning on intuitions and explicit knowledge. 

--Intuitive Thinking Style: Types of Intuition Scale (Pretz et al., 2014).
--Reflection/Intuitive Thinking: Cognitive Reflection Test (Frederick, 2005). 
--Creative Insight: Insight problems (see Chrysikou, 2006; Patrick & Ahmed, 2014)
--Intuitions of Universal Order and Belief in Divine Intervention (Weinberger et al., submitted)
--Basic demographic information
See above for calculation of implicit learning as well as potential composite measures of speed and accuracy.

1. Paired t-test
--Variable 1: Timing/Accuracy of intuition
--Variable 2: Timing/Accuracy of explicit knowledge
Intuitions are likely to emerge prior to explicit knowledge. Because participants will not be told that they should report intuitions first, the trajectory of conscious/accessible knowledge can be empirically tested with a t-test. We expect that the number of targets before participants report intuitions will be less than the number of targets before participants report explicit knowledge. We will also compare mean accuracy of intuitions and explicit knowledge.

2. Mixed effect model to obtain estimate of implicit learning:
--Level 1: Target number, Block condition (pattern or random), Button combination, Target number X Block condition interaction
--Level 2: Participant
--DV: Response Time

Mixed effects models are appropriate when several repeated measurements/observations (Level 1: target number) are nested within a higher level of data (Level 2: Participant; Goldstein, 2011; Longford, 1995), and have recently be used to examine sequence learning (Kahn et al., 2018; Karuza et al., 2019). The first 10 targets for each block will be excluded to allow for a brief familiarization. When building mixed effects models, it is important to carefully consider which slopes should be allowed to vary randomly. For theoretical reasons, we will set block condition to be random, as prior work has clearly demonstrated individual differences in the extent to which block condition influences RT (i.e., individual differences in implicit learning). The treatment of the remaining independent variables (i.e., fixed or random) will be resolved empirically; likelihood ratio (LR) tests will be performed to compare model fit when each independent variable is treated as a fixed or random slope in a stepwise manner. Slopes will only set to random if doing so improves model fit. In order to obtain a measure of implicit learning for each participant, we will estimate each participant’s variance from the average slope of block condition (using the most parsimonious model). All mixed effects models will be fit with maximum likelihood, unstructured variances and covariances, and robust standard errors. Significance tests will be two-sided.

Note that, once a participant indicates the presence of an intuition or explicit knowledge during a given block, we will no longer use information from that block in the mixed effect models to calculate implicit learning because the information is, presumably, no longer implicit (i.e., because the participant has reported some awareness). Crucially, participants are permitted to stop the block to report an intuition at any point. Thus, when this occurs is likely to vary widely from one participant to the next. Indeed, the timing of these reports are of central importance to our study. However, this does leave open the possibility that participants will have a substantially different number of Level 1 data points (i.e., how many targets before they signal an intuition/explicit knowledge). To mitigate this potential issue, all participants will complete 2 patterned blocks and 2 random blocks (order counterbalanced) prior to beginning the stage of the experiment when they are asked to report intuitions/explicit knowledge. If the number of pre-intuition data points vary widely from person-to-person, we may elect to constrain the mixed effects model (and subsequent implicit learning calculation) to just the 4 blocks that precede the stage of the experiment in which they can stop the sequence. 

3. Linear regression/zero-order correlations
DV: Intuitions; Explicit Knowledge
IV: Implicit learning (as derived from mixed effect model)
CV: TBD

Because intuitions have been theorized to emerge from implicit learning of regularity/coherence, we hypothesize that implicit learning will predict accuracy of intuitions. Because implicit learning – by its very calculation – will occur before intuition, there is a clear directionality of effect (i.e., implicit learning -> intuition). Additional data described in “Measured Variables” may be used as covariates if we find that they are meaningfully associated with intuitions. We will also run a regression model in which implicit learning predicts explicit knowledge.

4. Mediation analyses
IV: Implicit learning
MV: Intuitions
DV: Explicit Knowledge
CV: TBD

We will examine direct and indirect effects of implicit learning on explicit knowledge. Based on theoretical work on the role of intuition, we anticipate that it will mediate the effect of implicit learning.

q20.value: See previous note on possible reclassification of explicit knowledge as intuition. If a participant reports explicit knowledge before an intuition, we may recode their report as an intuition if they are unable to accurately reproduce the pattern.

q21.value: All significance tests will be two-tailed. We will use the standard p<.05 criteria, but also recognize the relative subjectivity and possible misuse of this criteria (see Wasserstein & Lazar, 2016). Thus, we will not rely on this single index as the sole basis of our interpretations.

q22.value:
As describe earlier, we will include attention checks at different times in the study. Failure to adequately answer these questions will result in data exclusion. Within the SRTT, we will also exclude all RTs > 1000 ms as well as the first 10 targets of each sequence. This is in line with prior work. 

We will also exclude the first 10 targets immediately following every time that a participant stops the sequence to report an intuition/explicit knowledge.

q23.value: Subjects with incomplete data will not be included in statistical models.

q24.value:
1. Mixed effects model for differences in RT based on knowledge

--Level 1: Target number, Block condition (pattern or random), Button combination, Target number X Block condition interaction, Knowledge (Pre-Intuition, Post-Intuition, Post-Explicit Knowledge)
--Level 2: Participant
--DV: Response Time

Using a similar model as described in statistical model 2, we will examine whether the kind of knowledge that one holds about the block type influences RT. Once again, all level 1 variables will be set to random if doing so improves model fit (with the exception of block condition, which will always be set to random).


2. Associations between implicit learning, intuitions, and explicit knowledge with associated personality traits/cognitive abilities. 

The below variables may be used in additional exploratory regression based models to examine how the emergence of intuitions relates to additional cognitive abilities and personality traits. If we find that these variables are meaningfully related to BOTH implicit learning and the emergence of intuitions/explicit knowledge, they may be used as covariate regressors in the primary analyses to obtain a more precise estimate of how our primary IVs and DVs interact. 

--Intuitive Thinking Style: Types of Intuition Scale (Pretz et al., 2014).
--Reflection/Intuitive Thinking: Cognitive Reflection Test (Frederick, 2005). 
--Creative Insight: Insight problems (see Chrysikou, 2006; Patrick & Ahmed, 2014)
--Intuitions of Universal Order and Belief in Divine Intervention (Weinberger et al., submitted)
--Basic demographic information

3. Additional analyses. 
Finally, it worth noting the inherent messiness of the data that we will be collecting for this study. Questions of how/when information enters conscious awareness have been of interest to psychologists and cognitive scientists for, essentially, as long as the fields have existed. Such inquiries concern relatively small, subtle changes in processing. Thus, there are almost certain to be additional exploratory analyses not yet conceived that will be required to provide a more thorough addressing of our primary questions – namely, how people become aware (presumably, intuitively and then more explicitly) of reoccurring patterns/regularities.

q25.value:

registration_responses.q1: Dynamic Development of Intuitions and Explicit Knowledge During Implicit Learning Paradigm
registration_responses.q3: Intuitions have been theorized to precede explicit awareness of information that is – at least initially – acquired implicitly (Epstein, 2010; Hodgkinson et al., 2008; Lieberman, 2000; Reber, 1989). In other words, intuitions develop based on incomplete implicit perceptions of regularity and coherence, and, in turn, influence subsequent beliefs, knowledge, and behavior (Bechara & Damasio, 2005; Epstein, 2010; Hodgkinson et al., 2008; Pacini & Epstein, 1999). However, there is surprisingly little empirical work to support intuitions based on implicit learning. The role of intuition on the development of more explicit knowledge and beliefs is also largely unknown. The present study will investigate the emergence of intuitions during an implicit learning paradigm, and examine how the accuracy of such intuitions influence later explicit knowledge.
registration_responses.q4:
1. Accurate intuitions will emerge prior to explicit knowledge… If intuitions develop from implicitly learned information, and serve as a bridge between nonconscious and more explicit representations, then individuals should report accurate intuitions of implicitly learned material prior to gaining explicit knowledge of the information. 

2. Individual differences in implicit learning will predict development of intuitions… Intuitions are said to develop based on incomplete perceptions of regularity or coherence. Therefore, stronger implicit learners should provide more accurate intuitions. We further hypothesize that they may develop intuitions more quickly.  

3. Explicit knowledge will be related to the quality of intuitions… We expect to observe a significant, positive association between accuracy of intuitions and explicit knowledge. 

4. Intuitions will influence the relationship between implicit learning and explicit knowledge… If intuitions serve as a bridge between implicit and explicit knowledge, the accuracy of one’s intuitions may mediate the effect of implicit learning on later explicit knowledge.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q11: Additional data collection prior to this registration was used for task development. No previously collected data will be used in the experiment/analyses described in this registration.
registration_responses.q13: Target sample size for this study is 100-125 participants, which will give us 80% power to detect a small-to-medium effect size for a linear regression model with up to 5 predictors at an alpha probability of .05. We will attempt to recruit 125-150 participants to account for any exclusions based on participant attention.
registration_responses.q14: We used the software program G*Power to perform a power analysis for a linear regression model with up to 5 predictors. Our goal was to obtain 80% power to detect a small to medium effect size (.1 - .15) at alpha error probability of .05.
registration_responses.q20: See previous note on possible reclassification of explicit knowledge as intuition. If a participant reports explicit knowledge before an intuition, we may recode their report as an intuition if they are unable to accurately reproduce the pattern.
registration_responses.q21: All significance tests will be two-tailed. We will use the standard p<.05 criteria, but also recognize the relative subjectivity and possible misuse of this criteria (see Wasserstein & Lazar, 2016). Thus, we will not rely on this single index as the sole basis of our interpretations.
registration_responses.q22:
As describe earlier, we will include attention checks at different times in the study. Failure to adequately answer these questions will result in data exclusion. Within the SRTT, we will also exclude all RTs > 1000 ms as well as the first 10 targets of each sequence. This is in line with prior work. 

We will also exclude the first 10 targets immediately following every time that a participant stops the sequence to report an intuition/explicit knowledge.
registration_responses.q23: Subjects with incomplete data will not be included in statistical models.
registration_responses.q24:
1. Mixed effects model for differences in RT based on knowledge

--Level 1: Target number, Block condition (pattern or random), Button combination, Target number X Block condition interaction, Knowledge (Pre-Intuition, Post-Intuition, Post-Explicit Knowledge)
--Level 2: Participant
--DV: Response Time

Using a similar model as described in statistical model 2, we will examine whether the kind of knowledge that one holds about the block type influences RT. Once again, all level 1 variables will be set to random if doing so improves model fit (with the exception of block condition, which will always be set to random).


2. Associations between implicit learning, intuitions, and explicit knowledge with associated personality traits/cognitive abilities. 

The below variables may be used in additional exploratory regression based models to examine how the emergence of intuitions relates to additional cognitive abilities and personality traits. If we find that these variables are meaningfully related to BOTH implicit learning and the emergence of intuitions/explicit knowledge, they may be used as covariate regressors in the primary analyses to obtain a more precise estimate of how our primary IVs and DVs interact. 

--Intuitive Thinking Style: Types of Intuition Scale (Pretz et al., 2014).
--Reflection/Intuitive Thinking: Cognitive Reflection Test (Frederick, 2005). 
--Creative Insight: Insight problems (see Chrysikou, 2006; Patrick & Ahmed, 2014)
--Intuitions of Universal Order and Belief in Divine Intervention (Weinberger et al., submitted)
--Basic demographic information

3. Additional analyses. 
Finally, it worth noting the inherent messiness of the data that we will be collecting for this study. Questions of how/when information enters conscious awareness have been of interest to psychologists and cognitive scientists for, essentially, as long as the fields have existed. Such inquiries concern relatively small, subtle changes in processing. Thus, there are almost certain to be additional exploratory analyses not yet conceived that will be required to provide a more thorough addressing of our primary questions – namely, how people become aware (presumably, intuitively and then more explicitly) of reoccurring patterns/regularities.

registration_responses.q8.question:
Participants will complete a modified version of the Serial Reaction Time Task (SRTT), a widely-used measure of implicit learning in which subjects must respond to dots that rapidly appear/disappear at different locations onscreen (some “blocks” are patterned; others are random; Nissen & Bullemer, 1987). Implicit learning is operationalized as the difference between random vs. patterned blocks to distinguish implicit learning from mere familiarity (Robertson, 2007).

After performing a number of SRTT blocks, participants will be informed that, at various points during the task, the dots will appear in a reoccurring pattern. They will then be instructed to indicate (1) when they have an intuition about whether the block is random or patterned and (2) when they are explicitly aware of whether or not there is a pattern. Participants will signal such knowledge be pressing a specific key on the keyboard, at which point they will be direct to a new screen and asked to indicate their level of knowledge. Participants who report explicit knowledge of a pattern will be asked to reproduce it. 

Notably, the experimental design allows for the possibility that participants may report explicit knowledge prior to reporting an intuition. We have intentionally allowed for this possibility in order to gain empirical support for our first hypothesis – and frequently-cited line of thinking – that intuitions emerge before explicit knowledge. However, in instances when a participant reports explicit knowledge before/without giving an intuition, we will take some steps to assess whether the knowledge is actually explicit. Because participants must reproduce the pattern if they report explicit knowledge, we will be able to ascertain whether or not their knowledge is likely to be explicit. For example, if a participant indicates explicit knowledge but cannot accurately indicate most of the repeating pattern, we may reclassify this report as an intuition. 

All participants will complete the same blocks, but order will be counterbalanced randomly. 

IV 1: Implicit learning: Operationalized as difference in responding during patterned vs. random blocks

DV 1: Intuitions: Operationalized both in terms of accuracy (e.g., does participant have an intuition of a pattern during a pattern block?) and speed (how long into the block before the participant reports an intuition). See above for alternative ways we may score intuition. 

DV 2: Explicit Knowledge: Operationalized both in terms of accuracy (e.g., does participant have explicit knowledge of a pattern during a pattern block? How many sequence elements can the participant reproduce?) and speed (how long into the block before the participant reports explicit knowledge).

MV 1: Intuitions -> does accuracy/speed of intuitions mediate relationship between implicit learning and explicit knowledge?
registration_responses.q12.question:
Data will be collected online through Prolific (https://www.prolific.co/). Participants will be paid approximately $9.00/hr. All participants who did not participate in previous version of this study (i.e., piloting) will be able to view the study. Participants will be eligible if they meet the following requirements: normal intellectual function, no significant medical disorder, age 18-55, not financially attached to Georgetown University, & fluent in English. 

Over the course of completing the study, participants will encounter a number of “attention checks”. Failure to respond appropriately to these questions will indicate inappropriate attention; participants who fail these questions will be excluded from analysis. Finally, the duration of each participants’ time to complete the study will be obtained; irregular completion times may also serve as grounds for exclusion.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Primary, hypothesis-driven variables: 

IV 1: Implicit Learning… Implicit learning will be operationalized as the difference in responding on patterned vs random blocks. This will be measured using mixed effects models, with target information (i.e., target number in the sequence, block type: pattern or random, button combination, target number x block type interaction) as Level 1 variables and Participant as the Level 2 variable. RT will be used as the DV. The first 10 targets of each block will be excluded to allow for a brief familiarization. We will also exclude all targets with an RT > 1000ms. Block condition will be treated as a random slope. All other level 1 variables will set to random if doing so improves model fit. In order to obtain a measure of implicit learning for each participant, we will estimate each participant’s variance from the average slope of block condition (using the most parsimonious model). 

DV 1: Intuitions… Participants will indicate the precise moment at which they develop intuitions. When they do this, participants will be directed to a separate screen to report whether they have an intuition that the targets are appearing as a pattern or an intuition that they are appearing randomly. We will record whether their intuitions are accurate as well as how many targets passed before they stopped the sequence to indicate the intuition. Both of these metrics (accuracy vs timing) may prove useful. If we observe a negative correlation between timing and accuracy (i.e., faster participants are more accurate), we may create a composite measure that incorporates both accuracy and timing. This measurement of intuition will serve as both a DV (as it relates to implicit learning) and as a MV (implicit learning  intuitions  explicit knowledge). Further, because participants are permitted to report explicit knowledge prior to intuitions, it will be important to determine whether explicit knowledge reported prior to an intuition is, in fact, explicit. Participants will be required to reproduce the pattern if they report explicit knowledge of a pattern. If participants who report explicit knowledge before an intuition are unable to demonstrate explicit knowledge (because they cannot produce the pattern), we may reclassify this judgement as an intuition. 

DV 2: Explicit Knowledge… Participants will also indicate when they have explicit knowledge of the pattern (again, by stopping the sequence). We will measure explicit knowledge by considering both accuracy and speed. Additionally, because participants will be asked to reproduce the pattern if they report explicit knowledge, we will also record the number of correct sequence elements that each participant can recall. We will examine how all 3 estimates of explicit knowledge relate to each other.

Secondary, exploratory variables:

We will collect additional information on each participant. The below variables may be used in additional exploratory regression based models to examine how the emergence of intuitions relates to other cognitive abilities and personality traits. If we find that these variables are meaningfully related to implicit learning and the emergence of intuitions/explicit knowledge, they may be used as covariate regressors in the primary analyses to obtain a more precise estimate of the effect of implicit learning on intuitions and explicit knowledge. 

--Intuitive Thinking Style: Types of Intuition Scale (Pretz et al., 2014).
--Reflection/Intuitive Thinking: Cognitive Reflection Test (Frederick, 2005). 
--Creative Insight: Insight problems (see Chrysikou, 2006; Patrick & Ahmed, 2014)
--Intuitions of Universal Order and Belief in Divine Intervention (Weinberger et al., submitted)
--Basic demographic information
registration_responses.q18.question: See above for calculation of implicit learning as well as potential composite measures of speed and accuracy.
registration_responses.q19.question:
1. Paired t-test
--Variable 1: Timing/Accuracy of intuition
--Variable 2: Timing/Accuracy of explicit knowledge
Intuitions are likely to emerge prior to explicit knowledge. Because participants will not be told that they should report intuitions first, the trajectory of conscious/accessible knowledge can be empirically tested with a t-test. We expect that the number of targets before participants report intuitions will be less than the number of targets before participants report explicit knowledge. We will also compare mean accuracy of intuitions and explicit knowledge.

2. Mixed effect model to obtain estimate of implicit learning:
--Level 1: Target number, Block condition (pattern or random), Button combination, Target number X Block condition interaction
--Level 2: Participant
--DV: Response Time

Mixed effects models are appropriate when several repeated measurements/observations (Level 1: target number) are nested within a higher level of data (Level 2: Participant; Goldstein, 2011; Longford, 1995), and have recently be used to examine sequence learning (Kahn et al., 2018; Karuza et al., 2019). The first 10 targets for each block will be excluded to allow for a brief familiarization. When building mixed effects models, it is important to carefully consider which slopes should be allowed to vary randomly. For theoretical reasons, we will set block condition to be random, as prior work has clearly demonstrated individual differences in the extent to which block condition influences RT (i.e., individual differences in implicit learning). The treatment of the remaining independent variables (i.e., fixed or random) will be resolved empirically; likelihood ratio (LR) tests will be performed to compare model fit when each independent variable is treated as a fixed or random slope in a stepwise manner. Slopes will only set to random if doing so improves model fit. In order to obtain a measure of implicit learning for each participant, we will estimate each participant’s variance from the average slope of block condition (using the most parsimonious model). All mixed effects models will be fit with maximum likelihood, unstructured variances and covariances, and robust standard errors. Significance tests will be two-sided.

Note that, once a participant indicates the presence of an intuition or explicit knowledge during a given block, we will no longer use information from that block in the mixed effect models to calculate implicit learning because the information is, presumably, no longer implicit (i.e., because the participant has reported some awareness). Crucially, participants are permitted to stop the block to report an intuition at any point. Thus, when this occurs is likely to vary widely from one participant to the next. Indeed, the timing of these reports are of central importance to our study. However, this does leave open the possibility that participants will have a substantially different number of Level 1 data points (i.e., how many targets before they signal an intuition/explicit knowledge). To mitigate this potential issue, all participants will complete 2 patterned blocks and 2 random blocks (order counterbalanced) prior to beginning the stage of the experiment when they are asked to report intuitions/explicit knowledge. If the number of pre-intuition data points vary widely from person-to-person, we may elect to constrain the mixed effects model (and subsequent implicit learning calculation) to just the 4 blocks that precede the stage of the experiment in which they can stop the sequence. 

3. Linear regression/zero-order correlations
DV: Intuitions; Explicit Knowledge
IV: Implicit learning (as derived from mixed effect model)
CV: TBD

Because intuitions have been theorized to emerge from implicit learning of regularity/coherence, we hypothesize that implicit learning will predict accuracy of intuitions. Because implicit learning – by its very calculation – will occur before intuition, there is a clear directionality of effect (i.e., implicit learning -> intuition). Additional data described in “Measured Variables” may be used as covariates if we find that they are meaningfully associated with intuitions. We will also run a regression model in which implicit learning predicts explicit knowledge.

4. Mediation analyses
IV: Implicit learning
MV: Intuitions
DV: Explicit Knowledge
CV: TBD

We will examine direct and indirect effects of implicit learning on explicit knowledge. Based on theoretical work on the role of intuition, we anticipate that it will mediate the effect of implicit learning.

attributes.title: Dynamic Climate and Light Scenarios in Indoor Open Office Environments
attributes.description: In this project, the effect of two different dynamic light scenarios on human well-being, performance and sleep are being tested in real life.

q1.value: Effects of dynamic lighting scenarios in an open office environment

q2.value: Maaike Kompier, Karin Smolders, Yvonne A. W. de Kort

q3.value:
In this six-week longitudinal study, we aim to contrast two dynamic lighting scenarios and test how differences in the light exposure profile (in terms of timing of exposure to brighter light) affect human comfort, alertness, performance and sleep. Both scenarios are tested against a control scenario in which light conditions are kept constant. The dynamic lighting conditions that are investigated are similar in amount of relatively bright light that participants are exposed to during their working day, however, they differ in their timing of exposure to this brighter light. We will test the effects of substantially brighter light for about 3.5 hours around midday, against substantially brighter light in the morning and at the end of the afternoon (again, amounting to about 3.5 hours). In terms of acute effects, this design will also allow us to examine at what time of day improvements in alertness and performance are to be expected.

The following research questions are addressed:
1) How can daytime light exposure affect sleep at night? 
1a) What are the effects of dynamic light scenarios (with a higher daily light dose) on sleep?
1b) How does the timing of bright light influence sleep?

2) How and when does bright light exposure influence human comfort, alertness and performance ?

q4.value:
It is expected that participants' sleep is better in the dynamic conditions (with a higher light dose) compared to the control condition. Although midday boosts are often suggested (and implemented) when scenarios imitate the daylight outside and when one tries to fight the after-lunch dip, our mathematical models based on the Kronauer model predict that the boosts at the beginning and end of day could be much more effective in advancing the circadian rhythm, and preventing negative effects of evening light exposure, and therefore improve sleep and in turn potentially also daytime functioning. Therefore, we expect that sleep will be best in the dynamic condition with light at the beginning and at the end of the day.

We expect higher levels of alertness and performance when participants are exposed to the higher illuminances as compared to regular levels. It is expected that these effects do not occur at all times of day.

Furthermore, exploratory analyses will be done to examine how visual and thermal comfort are influenced by the different light scenarios over the day.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
We employ a within-subject design to test the effect of lighting scenario on alertness, comfort, performance and sleep in an operational office. Only factor is manipulated, which is the light scenario. This factor has three levels (control, dynamic light A, dynamic light B), in which the control scenario and dynamic scenarios differ in dose, whereas dynamic light scenario A en B differ in timing of the bright light. The field study consists of six sampling weeks. In total, there are three groups of employees (about 10 participants per group) who are exposed to all scenarios, each for two weeks. The order of the scenarios is randomized using partial counterbalancing over the three groups.

Per week, participants have two measurement days. During a measurement day, they complete questionnaires: 1 sleep diary, ~8 experience sampling questionnaires and 1 day evaluation. Furthermore, they complete a spatial planning task twice, once in the morning (~10:30) and once in the afternoon (~15:00). Last, they wear an activity monitor and temperature sensors during the entire working day. A light sensor is worn from getting up until going to bed and an activity tracker is worn for 24 hours.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: Data is being collected at the moment. Data files have not yet been opened or processed.

question.value: Participants were recruited via their departmental managers based on their working location in the building of investigation. With their managers' permission, information sessions were organized for the employees after which potential participants had time to decide upon their participation. Participation is completely voluntary and participants are compensated with €50,-. Recruitment started in December 2019, 22-23rd of January instruction sessions were planned, and the 27th of January the study started. The study will be finished the 13nd of March.

q14.value:
The power analysis was done for the comparison of the KSS scores in bright light vs. the control condition. Our recent labstudies show that bright light can decrease sleepiness (KSS score) with 0.5 (on a scale ranging from 1 to 9) which is in line with other literature (Huiberts, Smolders, & De Kort, 2017; Smolders et al., 2012). The dynamic light for the afternoon will be designed to aim for a decrease in participants’ sleepiness of at least -0.5 (and thus an improvement in alertness). 

With 30 subjects, 4 measurements in each condition (1 per day for 4 days), an expected effect of -0.5, a random intercept for participants with a SD of 1 and residuals with a SD of 1.2, a power of 74% was calculated. In this simulation, multiple measurements within a measurement day could not be included. Multiple measurements within a measurement day are taken though (4 measurements/day) which is expected to increase our power to a level above 90%.

question.value: We will test the effects of substantially brighter light for about 3.5 hours around midday, against substantially brighter light in the morning and in the late afternoon (again, amounting to about 3.5 hours). Both will be tested against the control condition. The light will gradually (in 60 minutes) increase and decrease before and after these “high illuminance light boosts” aimed to facilitate a comfortable transition. In the files attached, there is a schematic overview of the scenario in which the timing of the light is clearly indicated and an overview (pdf) with the measurements (on both the eye and the desk) of the light used in the light scenarios (high and low illuminance) in a demo office with and without daylight. It should be noted that the measurements with daylight were taken prior to the start of the study in a similar (but not identical) office to the offices that were included in the study. These measurements were done at the 24th of January around 12:30, which was a cloudy day.

The following measurements will be done during the study:

-Indoor environment parameters (air velocity, air temperature, radiant temperature and relative humidity, horizontal and vertical irradiance): continuous measurements of the indoor climate relating to the temperature scenarios will be taken using a comfort index measurement tree. Raw data collection will be aggregated at different levels for later analysis (quarter hour, hour, day, week). 

-Personal light and temperature exposure using wearable sensors: continuous measurements with the LightLog (a personal clip-on light measurement device) and a iButton, will be collected during measurement days. iButtons are small battery-like temperature sensors that can record both ambient and skin temperature. Raw data collection will be aggregated at different levels later (quarter hour, hour, day, week). 

-Skin temperature - Two iButtons will be attached to 2 body sites (underarm and finger), which can give an indication of vasoconstriction/ vasodilation of the participants, which in turn relates to the thermal comfort of the participant (4 days per condition). 

-Personal actigraphy using wearables: Personal physical activity during the day will be measured using a three-axial accelerometer (Actigraph). The Actigraph is a lightweight activity monitor which is able to differentiate between sitting and standing on top of measuring accelerations. In this study, the Actigraph will be programmed to measure continuously during the conditions and will be attached to the around the hip of the participant (on the working days). Sleep will be registered using Axivity trackers that will be worn day and night on the measurement day.

-Subjective experiences: Self-reports will be assessed during the sampling days by means of experience sampling. The experience sampling contains of eight very brief questionnaires administerd during working hours and two diary questionnaires per measurement day (4 per condition). The random experience sampling questionnaires contains items regarding appraisals, alertness, thermal/visual comfort, thermal/visual acceptance, thermal/visual sensation, and eating and drinking behavior (~1 min.). The daily questionnaires consist of a morning questionnaire (~2 min.) in which the sleep timing and quality are assessed and a day evaluation at the end of the workday in which the subjective productivity of the day is assessed and worn clothing is indicated (~1 min.) . 
  
-Objective measures for cognitive performance: a 3-min cognitive task (hampshire tree task), administered once in the morning and once in the afternoon per sampling day.  

-Initial questionnaire: general participant information asking for participants’ age, gender, BMI, medication, inter-continental flights, chronotype, general sleep timing and quality (MCTQ by Roenneberg, Wirz-Justice, and Merrow (2003)), general health (SF-36 by van der Zee and Sanderman (2012) ),  and general sensitivity for light

Light logger: log transformation, and then averaged into half hourly light exposure
iButton: hand temperature - arm temperature = Temperature gradient, and then averaged into half hourly temperature gradient
Actigraph: sedentary behavior
Axivity tracker: sleep duration (=sleep end - sleep start) and midsleep (=sleep start + ((sleep end - sleep start)/2))
daily morning questionnaire (~2 min.) in which the sleep timing and quality is assessed (4 days per condition): sleep onset (=sleep start), sleep offset (=sleep end), sleep latency (bed time - sleep start), midsleep (=sleep start + ((sleep end - sleep start)/2)), sleep quality and sleep duration (=sleep end - sleep start)
weight and length: BMI (weight / (length*length))
general sleep timing and quality:  midsleep following the guidelines by Roenneberg, Wirz-Justice, and Merrow (2003) and quality
general health: item 1,3 and 5 are reverse coded. ((sum of raw scale score-5)/20)*100

Multilevel models will be run for all different dependent variables (alertness, performance, sleep duration, sleep timing, sleep quality). The data for alertness, comfort, and performance are structured as follows: observations nested within days, nested within weeks, nested with participants. Sleep-related variables and end-of-the-day assessments are only nested within weeks, nested within participants. This means that 4-level models will be run for the experience sampling data and 3-level models for the diary data. Based on the intraclass correlations of the null models, we will determine the hierarchical structure of the multilevel analyses. 

Relevant covariates that should be included in the models will be determined based on preliminary correlational analyses and visualizations (f.e. correlational plots). Control variables that correlate sufficiently (i.e. a significant correlation that is larger than .4) with the dependent variable and do not show multicollinearity with other predictors will be included as covariates.

For the analysis of sleep related variables, the light condition (control, A or B) will be used as predictor in the model. Contrast analyses on this model will be done to answer the research questions. 
Sleep (duration, timing and quality) will be compared between the control condition and the mean of the dynamic conditions to answer research question 1a). To answer research question 1b) these variables will be compared between the two dynamic scenarios. For a schematic visualization of these comparisons, see the attached figure.

To test the effect of bright light on alertness and performance, the momentary light setting, the time of day and the interaction thereof will be included in the model. Per time of day (morning, mid-day, afternoon), contrast analyses will be done comparing the bright light group, with the regular light groups (ie. as in the visualization that is added: for morning and afternoon: mean of control+A vs. B, for midday: mean of control + B vs. A).

registration_responses.q1: Effects of dynamic lighting scenarios in an open office environment
registration_responses.q2: Maaike Kompier, Karin Smolders, Yvonne A. W. de Kort
registration_responses.q3:
In this six-week longitudinal study, we aim to contrast two dynamic lighting scenarios and test how differences in the light exposure profile (in terms of timing of exposure to brighter light) affect human comfort, alertness, performance and sleep. Both scenarios are tested against a control scenario in which light conditions are kept constant. The dynamic lighting conditions that are investigated are similar in amount of relatively bright light that participants are exposed to during their working day, however, they differ in their timing of exposure to this brighter light. We will test the effects of substantially brighter light for about 3.5 hours around midday, against substantially brighter light in the morning and at the end of the afternoon (again, amounting to about 3.5 hours). In terms of acute effects, this design will also allow us to examine at what time of day improvements in alertness and performance are to be expected.

The following research questions are addressed:
1) How can daytime light exposure affect sleep at night? 
1a) What are the effects of dynamic light scenarios (with a higher daily light dose) on sleep?
1b) How does the timing of bright light influence sleep?

2) How and when does bright light exposure influence human comfort, alertness and performance ?
registration_responses.q4:
It is expected that participants' sleep is better in the dynamic conditions (with a higher light dose) compared to the control condition. Although midday boosts are often suggested (and implemented) when scenarios imitate the daylight outside and when one tries to fight the after-lunch dip, our mathematical models based on the Kronauer model predict that the boosts at the beginning and end of day could be much more effective in advancing the circadian rhythm, and preventing negative effects of evening light exposure, and therefore improve sleep and in turn potentially also daytime functioning. Therefore, we expect that sleep will be best in the dynamic condition with light at the beginning and at the end of the day.

We expect higher levels of alertness and performance when participants are exposed to the higher illuminances as compared to regular levels. It is expected that these effects do not occur at all times of day.

Furthermore, exploratory analyses will be done to examine how visual and thermal comfort are influenced by the different light scenarios over the day.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to any human observation of the data
registration_responses.q11: Data is being collected at the moment. Data files have not yet been opened or processed.
registration_responses.q14:
The power analysis was done for the comparison of the KSS scores in bright light vs. the control condition. Our recent labstudies show that bright light can decrease sleepiness (KSS score) with 0.5 (on a scale ranging from 1 to 9) which is in line with other literature (Huiberts, Smolders, & De Kort, 2017; Smolders et al., 2012). The dynamic light for the afternoon will be designed to aim for a decrease in participants’ sleepiness of at least -0.5 (and thus an improvement in alertness). 

With 30 subjects, 4 measurements in each condition (1 per day for 4 days), an expected effect of -0.5, a random intercept for participants with a SD of 1 and residuals with a SD of 1.2, a power of 74% was calculated. In this simulation, multiple measurements within a measurement day could not be included. Multiple measurements within a measurement day are taken though (4 measurements/day) which is expected to increase our power to a level above 90%.
registration_responses.q23: The multilevel models that we are using deal well with missing data.
registration_responses.q24: The exploratory analyses to study the response of visual and thermal comfort to the light conditions will be in line with the analyses for alertness and performance.
registration_responses.q8.question:
We employ a within-subject design to test the effect of lighting scenario on alertness, comfort, performance and sleep in an operational office. Only factor is manipulated, which is the light scenario. This factor has three levels (control, dynamic light A, dynamic light B), in which the control scenario and dynamic scenarios differ in dose, whereas dynamic light scenario A en B differ in timing of the bright light. The field study consists of six sampling weeks. In total, there are three groups of employees (about 10 participants per group) who are exposed to all scenarios, each for two weeks. The order of the scenarios is randomized using partial counterbalancing over the three groups.

Per week, participants have two measurement days. During a measurement day, they complete questionnaires: 1 sleep diary, ~8 experience sampling questionnaires and 1 day evaluation. Furthermore, they complete a spatial planning task twice, once in the morning (~10:30) and once in the afternoon (~15:00). Last, they wear an activity monitor and temperature sensors during the entire working day. A light sensor is worn from getting up until going to bed and an activity tracker is worn for 24 hours.
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants were recruited via their departmental managers based on their working location in the building of investigation. With their managers' permission, information sessions were organized for the employees after which potential participants had time to decide upon their participation. Participation is completely voluntary and participants are compensated with €50,-. Recruitment started in December 2019, 22-23rd of January instruction sessions were planned, and the 27th of January the study started. The study will be finished the 13nd of March.
registration_responses.q16.question: We will test the effects of substantially brighter light for about 3.5 hours around midday, against substantially brighter light in the morning and in the late afternoon (again, amounting to about 3.5 hours). Both will be tested against the control condition. The light will gradually (in 60 minutes) increase and decrease before and after these “high illuminance light boosts” aimed to facilitate a comfortable transition. In the files attached, there is a schematic overview of the scenario in which the timing of the light is clearly indicated and an overview (pdf) with the measurements (on both the eye and the desk) of the light used in the light scenarios (high and low illuminance) in a demo office with and without daylight. It should be noted that the measurements with daylight were taken prior to the start of the study in a similar (but not identical) office to the offices that were included in the study. These measurements were done at the 24th of January around 12:30, which was a cloudy day.
registration_responses.q17.question:
The following measurements will be done during the study:

-Indoor environment parameters (air velocity, air temperature, radiant temperature and relative humidity, horizontal and vertical irradiance): continuous measurements of the indoor climate relating to the temperature scenarios will be taken using a comfort index measurement tree. Raw data collection will be aggregated at different levels for later analysis (quarter hour, hour, day, week). 

-Personal light and temperature exposure using wearable sensors: continuous measurements with the LightLog (a personal clip-on light measurement device) and a iButton, will be collected during measurement days. iButtons are small battery-like temperature sensors that can record both ambient and skin temperature. Raw data collection will be aggregated at different levels later (quarter hour, hour, day, week). 

-Skin temperature - Two iButtons will be attached to 2 body sites (underarm and finger), which can give an indication of vasoconstriction/ vasodilation of the participants, which in turn relates to the thermal comfort of the participant (4 days per condition). 

-Personal actigraphy using wearables: Personal physical activity during the day will be measured using a three-axial accelerometer (Actigraph). The Actigraph is a lightweight activity monitor which is able to differentiate between sitting and standing on top of measuring accelerations. In this study, the Actigraph will be programmed to measure continuously during the conditions and will be attached to the around the hip of the participant (on the working days). Sleep will be registered using Axivity trackers that will be worn day and night on the measurement day.

-Subjective experiences: Self-reports will be assessed during the sampling days by means of experience sampling. The experience sampling contains of eight very brief questionnaires administerd during working hours and two diary questionnaires per measurement day (4 per condition). The random experience sampling questionnaires contains items regarding appraisals, alertness, thermal/visual comfort, thermal/visual acceptance, thermal/visual sensation, and eating and drinking behavior (~1 min.). The daily questionnaires consist of a morning questionnaire (~2 min.) in which the sleep timing and quality are assessed and a day evaluation at the end of the workday in which the subjective productivity of the day is assessed and worn clothing is indicated (~1 min.) . 
  
-Objective measures for cognitive performance: a 3-min cognitive task (hampshire tree task), administered once in the morning and once in the afternoon per sampling day.  

-Initial questionnaire: general participant information asking for participants’ age, gender, BMI, medication, inter-continental flights, chronotype, general sleep timing and quality (MCTQ by Roenneberg, Wirz-Justice, and Merrow (2003)), general health (SF-36 by van der Zee and Sanderman (2012) ),  and general sensitivity for light
registration_responses.q18.question:
Light logger: log transformation, and then averaged into half hourly light exposure
iButton: hand temperature - arm temperature = Temperature gradient, and then averaged into half hourly temperature gradient
Actigraph: sedentary behavior
Axivity tracker: sleep duration (=sleep end - sleep start) and midsleep (=sleep start + ((sleep end - sleep start)/2))
daily morning questionnaire (~2 min.) in which the sleep timing and quality is assessed (4 days per condition): sleep onset (=sleep start), sleep offset (=sleep end), sleep latency (bed time - sleep start), midsleep (=sleep start + ((sleep end - sleep start)/2)), sleep quality and sleep duration (=sleep end - sleep start)
weight and length: BMI (weight / (length*length))
general sleep timing and quality:  midsleep following the guidelines by Roenneberg, Wirz-Justice, and Merrow (2003) and quality
general health: item 1,3 and 5 are reverse coded. ((sum of raw scale score-5)/20)*100
registration_responses.q19.question:
Multilevel models will be run for all different dependent variables (alertness, performance, sleep duration, sleep timing, sleep quality). The data for alertness, comfort, and performance are structured as follows: observations nested within days, nested within weeks, nested with participants. Sleep-related variables and end-of-the-day assessments are only nested within weeks, nested within participants. This means that 4-level models will be run for the experience sampling data and 3-level models for the diary data. Based on the intraclass correlations of the null models, we will determine the hierarchical structure of the multilevel analyses. 

Relevant covariates that should be included in the models will be determined based on preliminary correlational analyses and visualizations (f.e. correlational plots). Control variables that correlate sufficiently (i.e. a significant correlation that is larger than .4) with the dependent variable and do not show multicollinearity with other predictors will be included as covariates.

For the analysis of sleep related variables, the light condition (control, A or B) will be used as predictor in the model. Contrast analyses on this model will be done to answer the research questions. 
Sleep (duration, timing and quality) will be compared between the control condition and the mean of the dynamic conditions to answer research question 1a). To answer research question 1b) these variables will be compared between the two dynamic scenarios. For a schematic visualization of these comparisons, see the attached figure.

To test the effect of bright light on alertness and performance, the momentary light setting, the time of day and the interaction thereof will be included in the model. Per time of day (morning, mid-day, afternoon), contrast analyses will be done comparing the bright light group, with the regular light groups (ie. as in the visualization that is added: for morning and afternoon: mean of control+A vs. B, for midday: mean of control + B vs. A).

attributes.title: Physical Activity in Children and Adolescents with Pediatric Hip Disorders

summary.value: The role of physical activity in patients with healed pediatric hip conditions is still poorly understood. This scoping review will examine and map the pre-existing literature in order to understand the purpose, quality, and outcome of physical activity measurements in this population.
