attributes.title: Examining the Precision of Approximate Number Computation in Adults

q1.value: Examining the Precision of Approximate Number Computation in Adults

q3.value:
This study aims to confirm our initial exploratory study examining the precision of approximate number computation in adults. In the initial study, we tested 40 adults. Subjects were asked to perform a mental manipulation on Approximate Number System (ANS) representation, and then to compare the output of that representation to a visible array. Within subjects, adults performed three types of manipulation. In the Basic manipulation, an array of dots moved behind an occluder, and subjects had to maintain the ANS representation in working memory. In the Summation condition, two arrays of dots moved sequentially behind an occluder. Subjects had to mentally sum these arrays, a computation that can be accomplished by maintaining a running total in working memory (i.e. updating an ANS representation; see Barth et al., 2005). In the Difference (or Solve-for-x) condition, an array was occluded, an unknown set was added, and then the occluder was removed to reveal the final set. Subjects had to determine the quantity that was added, a computation that requires maintaining two separate ANS representations in working memory and taking their difference (see Kibbe & Feigenson, 2015, 2017). We aimed to examine whether these different types of mental manipulation differentially impacted the precision of their outputs.
In the initial exploratory study, our primary analysis of interest was a repeated measures ANOVA with Manipulation Condition (Basic, Summation, Difference) and Ratio (3:4, 4:5, 5:6, 6:7, 7:8) as within-subjects factors. We found the precision of the outputs of computations with the ANS were influenced by the manipulation that subjects were asked to perform and the level of difficulty of the comparison (ratios between computed and test dot arrays). Subjects’ performance decreased overall as the ratio between the comparison arrays decreased. Subjects also performed roughly equally in Basic and Summation conditions, and worse in the Difference condition. An interaction was found between Manipulation Condition and Ratio; performance across manipulation conditions converged at the hardest level (smallest ratio, 7:8). Figure 1 shows the data from this experiment. Observed power for main effects and the interaction were high (1-beta > .9). In an exploratory analysis, we looked at whether performance in each condition was correlated with ANS acuity which was measured via the standardized Panamath task (the psychophysical assessment of number sense acuity, Halberda & Ly, 2015). We found a moderate positive correlation between the performance in Summation condition and ANS acuity, but not in the other two conditions, though a suggestive trend was found in the performance in the Basic condition. 
In the replication, we intend to test a new group of 40 adults using the same tasks, but with double the test trials in each condition for the primary computation manipulation task.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: Adults will perform better in Basic and Summation conditions than in the Difference condition.

Hypothesis 2: Performance in all manipulation conditions will decrease as the ratio between the computed and test arrays become smaller.

Hypothesis 3: We will again observe an interaction between the manipulation condition and ratio, with performance converging as the comparisons become more difficult.

A secondary goal of the current study is to examine the extent to which performance on our task correlates with performance on Panamath, a measurement of ANS acuity. We do not have a strong prediction with respect to correlation between performance on our task and Panamath performance. We may continue to find that only the Summation condition correlates with Panamath performance. However, it is also possible that both the Basic and Summation conditions will correlate with Panamath performance, while Difference may continue to not be correlated with Panamath.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Participants will receive 2 practice trials and then 60 test trials in each of the computation manipulation conditions, Basic, Summation, Difference, presented in blocks. 

In each test trial of the Basic condition, participants will first see an array of dots on the left of the screen, which are then covered by an occluder. A comparison array of dots will then appear on the right side of the screen, and participants will be asked to choose which array is larger, the occluded array or the visible array (Figure 2, top panel). 

In each test trial of the Summation condition, participants will first see an array of dots on the left side of the screen, which are then covered by an occluder. Another array of dots will appear above the occluder and then move behind the occluder. The comparison array will then appear on the right side of the screen.  Participants are asked to choose which array is larger, the sum of the two occluded arrays together or the visible array (Figure, middle panel). 

In each test trial of the Difference condition, participants will first see an array of dots on the left side of the screen, which are then covered by an occluder. The occluder is then removed to reveal that the array has increased in quantity. The comparison array will then appear on the right side of the screen. Participants are asked to choose which array is larger, the difference between the starting and ending quantities or the visible array (Figure 2, bottom panel). 

Numerosities range from 5 to 66. There are five possible comparison ratios: 3:4(0.75), 4:5(0.8), 5:6(0.83), 6:7(0.86), 7:8(0.88).

Following the primary task, we will also measure ANS acuity using the standardized Panamath task. Participants will be told to compare the quantity of the arrays in two locations on the computer screen. We presented four ratio bins(min-max): (0.42-0.45), (0.75-0.8), (0.82-0.88), (0.88-0.93). The number of dots within each rectangle was always between 5 and 21. The dots appear on the screen for 600ms followed by a blank screen that remained until the participant press a key response. Participants completed 2 practice trials and 160 test trials.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited from Boston University through an online system and will participate for course credit. Participants will be seated at the table, with a laptop facing them. The participants will orally report the judgements, and the experimenter will manually record the responses. After the participants respond, the experimenter will proceed to the next trial without providing feedback to the responses.

Participants who voluntarily terminate the study early will be removed from analyses. Participants who achieve 60% correct or less on either of the easiest two ratios in the Basic condition (suggesting guessing) also will be excluded (note: mean performance in our original exploratory experiment on these trials was higher than 85%).

q13.value: Our target sample size is 40 young adults with normal or corrected-to-normal vision.

q14.value: A power analysis using the smallest effect size from our original study for a 3 X 5 repeated measures ANOVA (the interaction: f=.35, alpha = .05, power=.8) suggested a total sample of n=21. We opted to roughly double this sample to match our original sample in order to facilitate comparison between the original study and its replication.

question.value:
Independent (within-subjects)
1.	Manipulation (Basic, Summation, Difference) 
2.	Ratio between manipulated array and the comparison array (3:4, 4:5, 5:6, 6:7, 7:8).

Dependent
1.	Accuracy (correct/incorrect) of the primary task.

Additional measures:
1.	ANS accuracy (on Panamath)

Coding
Accuracy will be measured as percent of trials on whether the larger quantity was correctly selected in each Condition for each Ratio.

Planned Analyses
1.	Repeated measures ANOVA on accuracy with Condition (Basic, Summation, Difference) and Ratio (3:4, 4:5, 5:6, 6:7, 7:8) as within-subjects factors.
2.	One sample t-tests comparing the mean accuracy to chance (50%) in each Condition for each Ratio (alpha=.01 to correct for multiple comparisons within each Condition).
3.	Correlation between accuracy in each of the three Conditions and ANS acuity performance.

Halberda, J., & Ly, R. (2015). PANAmath: The psychophysical assessment of number-sense acuity. Manuscript in Preparation.

attributes.title: Efficacy and Safety of Shenqi Compound for the Treatment of Diabetic Macroangiopathy: A Protocol for Systematic Review and Meta-analysis
attributes.description:
Diabetic macroangiopathy is a further complication of diabetes mellitus and is the leading cause of death for diabetic patients. Shenqi compound is a traditional Chinese medicine formula widely used in the treatment of diabetes and diabetic macroangiopathy. At present, there is only one systematic review on shenqi compound in the treatment of diabetes. However, no meta-analysis has evaluated the efficacy and safety of shenqi compound on diabetic macroangiopathy.
From its establishment to March 1, 2020, three English databases and four Chinese medical databases will be searched. Then, according to the established inclusion and exclusion criteria, the two methodologically trained researchers will select qualified articles by reading titles, abstracts and full texts. The deviation risk will be assessed using the tools of Cochrane Collaboration. We will conduct a meta-analysis of fasting blood glucose, postprandial blood glucose, glycosylated hemoglobin and other results. We will also complete heterogeneity assessment, subgroup analysis and sensitivity analysis for the data.
The results will be published at a peer-reviewed journal.
 In this study, we will systematically evaluate the evidence of shenqi compound in the treatment of diabetic macroangiopathy. Our research is supposed to provide evidence-based support for clinical practice.

q1.value: Efficacy and Safety of Shenqi Compound for the Treatment of Diabetic Macroangiopathy: A Protocol for Systematic Review and Meta-analysis

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Three English database and four Chinese medical databases will be searched from its inception to March 1, 2020. Then two methodological trained researchers will screen the qualified articles by reading the title, abstract and full texts according to an established inclusion and exclusion criteria. The assessment of risk of bias will be conducted by using the Cochrane collaboration’s tool. we will conduct meta-analyses for fasting blood glucose, postprandial blood glucose, HbA1c and other outcomes. The heterogeneity of data will be evaluated by Cochrane X2 and I2 tests. We establish three hypotheses before the subgroup analysis actually starts: Disease status at baseline, duration of intervention, type of concomitant medication. We will conduct sensitivity analysis to evaluate the stability of the results, funnel plot analysis and Egger’s test to evaluate the publication bias, and assessment for the quality of evidence by the Grading of Recommendations Assessment, Development and Evaluate system.
